flashcards.front: How many categories in Eleven Demands?
flashcards.back: Three categories: Issue of General Interest (6 demands), Specific Bourgeois Demands (3 demands), Specific Peasant Demands (2 demands)
Six demands covering: Army/civil services reduction, prohibition, CID reforms, Arms Act amendment, political prisoners release
Three demands: Rupee-sterling exchange rate, textile protection, coastal shipping reservation - economic interests of Indian businessmen
Two demands: Slash land revenue 50%, abolish salt tax/monopoly - addressing rural/agrarian grievances
Demand 11: Abolish salt tax and government monopoly - became symbol of Civil Disobedience Movement (Salt March)
Bourgeois (3): Exchange rate, textile, shipping | Peasant (2): Land revenue, salt | General (1): Army/civil expenditure
Combining general political (6), bourgeois economic (3), and peasant agrarian (2) - building broad anti-colonial coalition

mcq.question: How many demands in Gandhi's Eleven Demands?
mcq.explanation: Gandhi's Eleven Demands - exactly 11 demands organized in three categories.

mcq.question: How many categories in Gandhi's Eleven Demands?
mcq.explanation: Three categories: Issue of General Interest, Specific Bourgeois Demands, Specific Peasant Demands.

mcq.question: How many demands under 'Issue of General Interest'?
mcq.explanation: Issue of General Interest contained 6 demands.

mcq.question: How many 'Specific Bourgeois Demands'?
mcq.explanation: Specific Bourgeois Demands contained 3 demands.

mcq.question: How many 'Specific Peasant Demands'?
mcq.explanation: Specific Peasant Demands contained 2 demands.

mcq.question: Which demand called for 50% reduction in Army/civil services expenditure?
mcq.explanation: Demand 1 (General Interest): Implement 50% reduction in expenditure on Army and civil services.

mcq.question: Enforce total prohibition was which category?
mcq.explanation: Demand 2 (General Interest): Enforce total prohibition.

mcq.question: CID reforms belonged to which category?
mcq.explanation: Demand 3 (General Interest): Institute reforms in Criminal Investigation Department (CID).

mcq.question: Arms Act amendment was under?
mcq.explanation: Demand 4 (General Interest): Amend Arms Act to enable popular control over firearms licenses.

mcq.question: Release political prisoners was which demand?
mcq.explanation: Demand 5 (General Interest): Release political prisoners.

mcq.question: Postal Reservation Bill was under?
mcq.explanation: Demand 6 (General Interest): Approve the Postal Reservation Bill.

mcq.question: Rupee-sterling exchange ratio demand belonged to?
mcq.explanation: Demand 7 (Bourgeois): Decrease rupee-sterling exchange ratio to 1s 4d.

mcq.question: What was the desired rupee-sterling exchange ratio?
mcq.explanation: Demand 7 (Bourgeois): Decrease the rupee-sterling exchange ratio to 1s 4d.

mcq.question: Textile protection was which category?
mcq.explanation: Demand 8 (Bourgeois): Introduce textile protection - protecting Indian textile industry.

mcq.question: Coastal shipping reservation was?
mcq.explanation: Demand 9 (Bourgeois): Reserve coastal shipping for Indians.

mcq.question: Slash land revenue by what percentage?
mcq.explanation: Demand 10 (Peasant): Slash land revenue by 50%.

mcq.question: Land revenue reduction was which category?
mcq.explanation: Demand 10 (Peasant): Slash land revenue by 50%.

mcq.question: Abolish salt tax was which category?
mcq.explanation: Demand 11 (Peasant): Abolish the salt tax and government's salt monopoly.

mcq.question: What did Demand 11 call for abolishing?
options: Salt tax and government salt monopoly
mcq.explanation: Demand 11 (Peasant): Abolish the salt tax and the government's salt monopoly.

mcq.question: Which demand became symbol of Civil Disobedience?
mcq.explanation: Demand 11 (Peasant): Abolish salt tax/monopoly became symbol - Gandhi's Salt March (1930).

comprehensive.question: Analyze the three-category structure of Gandhi's Eleven Demands: Issue of General Interest (6), Specific Bourgeois Demands (3), and Specific Peasant Demands (2), examining how this reflected Gandhi's strategy of building a broad anti-colonial coalition.
comprehensive.answer: Three-Category Structure: Issue of General Interest (6 demands): 1) 50% reduction in Army/civil services expenditure, 2) Enforce total prohibition, 3) CID reforms, 4) Arms Act amendment (popular control over firearms licenses), 5) Release political prisoners, 6) Approve Postal Reservation Bill.

comprehensive.question: Examine the economic demands across all three categories, analyzing how they challenged British colonial economic exploitation through currency (rupee-sterling), trade (textile protection, coastal shipping), taxation (land revenue, salt), and expenditure (Army/civil services).
comprehensive.answer: Economic Demands Distribution: General Interest: Demand 1 - 50% reduction in Army/civil services expenditure. Bourgeois: Demands 7-9 - Exchange rate, textile protection, coastal shipping. Peasant: Demands 10-11 - Land revenue reduction, salt tax abolition.

comprehensive.question: Compare the 'Issue of General Interest' (6 demands) with the specific class demands (Bourgeois 3, Peasant 2), analyzing which category most challenged colonial power structures and why Gandhi might have emphasized general over specific demands numerically.
comprehensive.answer: Issue of General Interest (6 demands): 1) 50% reduction in Army/civil services expenditure. 2) Enforce total prohibition. 3) CID reforms. 4) Arms Act amendment (popular control over firearms licenses). 5) Release political prisoners. 6) Approve Postal Reservation Bill.
